author: Silvanus (Silas) and Timothy are named with the author, Paul (as they are at the opening of 1 Thessalonians), because they were his co-laborers in establishing the Thessalonian church (see Acts 17:1–9).
date: This epistle was written in AD 51, probably from Corinth.
theme: Stand fast by means of apostolic teaching. Some of the Thessalonians had been shaken in their faith by speculations on Christ’s return; some even said the day of the Lord had already come (2:2). As a result, these people had lost holiness of life. Paul counters such traditions of men with apostolic tradition (2:15; 3:6). Subthemes include Paul’s gratitude for the people’s faithfulness (1:3; 2:13) and for God’s faithfulness to His people (3:3).
